ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Strengthened my love for TYA; learned about what professionals in TYA are doing; learned history and made work!
I learned all about different works in and perspectives on Theater for Young Audiences, in addition to collaborating with my classmates to make our own TYA works.
I learned the differences and similarities between creating theater for adults and young people, and how to work well in a group to create theater.

I learned so much! Just a few of the things I learned are: challenges of children's theater, the state of children's theater today, different philosophies around children's theater, how to put together and perform short pieces in limited time, etc. I've grown immensely as an artist and as a person interested in working with children.

The most important insight: that TYA is a flourishing branch of theater in urgent need of care, investment, community collaboration, and humanity. What ingredients of storytelling architecture, theme, music, humor, and audience participation (criteria our class developed!) does TYA needs to be resonant for children and families. I and many of my peers really took this mission to heart--along with the power of TYA's brand of captivating, compassionate storytellingand I left this class so compelled in the power of the medium. I want to pursue a career in YA theater and literature now!

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: We built a community of theater makers! I loved the solo performances and would have loved to have a piece we write individually performed by the others (like the solo storybook pieces).

This course had no weaknesses. It was a wonderful time, and everything we did enhanced our knowledge of the process of creating work for children and families. It also put us in touch with our own childhoods as we enjoyed the TYA works of our peers.
This course was absolutely beautiful and has the best atmosphere, I cannot think of a weakness.

This class was incredible. The professors and students brought great warmth, enthusiasm, and insight into the classroom. I felt encouraged and safe stretching outside of my comfort zone. Students had a lot of autonomy, so we could mold the class to make it what we wanted it to be. Assignments and activities were creative, enjoyable, and informative.

The only weaknesses of the class were that many readings were fairly old and the class was occasionally disorganized, particularly towards the end as we started running out of time. The final project, in particular, was a bit chaotic. Overall, however, the class was wonderful.

STRENGTHS: incredible professors both with extensive theater/TYA experience! They brought us to consider important questions about TYA today, probe the creative depths of our childhood, and grow as creators. A close class community of students who gave so much of themselves throughout the course. Insightful readings and assignments that really challenge you! No weaknesses!

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes!! You'll collaborate and create in a way you don't get to in any other class.
I would recommend this course to anyone who is passionate about considering and creating entertainment for young audiences.
Yes, I loved this class I think everyone should take it regardless of if they already do theater. They will learn to love it!!
YES! It was a joy. I would recommend this course in a heartbeat.

Yes!!! This class was revelatory, largely because it involved so many creative projects--or tudes, mini-productions of TYA. Our projects were original, fun, all performed in front of each other--not to mention group-based (one of the first times I *thoroughly* enjoyed working with peers academically)and inspired by our discussions, fascinating TYA readings (+ some fantastic plays!), conversations with big time TYA practitioners and directors, our own work, and Professor Margolin and Roberts' insights. LOVED this course--it helped me realize one of my passions (and even helped me, and all of us, gain an industry connection in the TYA world!)
